content.title: Weatherill quits parliament - The Australian
content.desc: Jay Weatherill, who yesterday announce­d his resignation from state parliament, has ruled out enteri­ng federal politics, saying he could think of nothing worse. The 54-year-old former South Australian Labor premier said he had “run my race” and it was “time to pass the baton on”. “I don’t like the culture and the dynamic of federal politics,” Mr Weatherill said. “I have no plans other than looking after two little girls and a wife, and some ageing parents. “Politics is always about the ­future and I could not see myself running in 2022. Former leaders hanging around politics doesn’t have a...

content.title: Cheek, mischief and the final day of Jay - The Advertiser
content.desc: There’s a bit more rattiness and cheek than usual, and the people who are meant to be keeping the joint running in good order let a bit more mischief go than usual. This Thursday had more nostalgia and magnanimity than is usual as MPs farewelled the grand old building for summer, and a past premier said goodbye to the place forever. Former premier Jay Weatherill’s decision to pull the pin on a 16-year career, almost all of which was spent as a member of Cabinet, surprised no one. It seemed destined to come — the only question had been around timing. And it triggered speeches from political ...

content.title: ‘I’m proud of my achievements’ - The Australian
content.desc: Former South Australian Labor premier Jay Weatherill will retire from state politics and outline his exit plans during today’s final state parliamentary sitting day of the year. Mr Weatherill, 54, has sat on the opposition backbench since leading Labor to defeat at the March state election. The former lawyer entered parliament in 2002 and went straight into cabinet, serving in various ministerial positions until he took over as premier in 2011 from Mike Rann following a cross-factional deal orchestrated by the union boss Peter Malinauskas. Mr Malinauskas, who Mr Weatherill later brought int...

content.title: Former SA premier Jay Weatherill retires (full speech) | ABC News - ABC News
content.desc: Jay Weatherill, the former Labor South Australian premier, announces his retirement from state politics. The former lawyer was first elected in 2002 and was directly appointed to premier Mike Rann's cabinet. He replaced Mr Rann as premier in 2011. content.title: Jay Weatherill quits politics - The Advertiser
content.desc: Mr Weatherill chose State Parliament’s final scheduled sitting day of the year to confirm his exit, after 16 years of service, which will trigger a by-election in his safe western suburbs seat of Cheltenham. Flanked by his wife and two daughters in a press conference yesterday, Mr Weatherill said he would devote himself to family life and had no plans for the next phase in his career. Mr Weatherill said he was proud of how the State Government under his leadership handled the fallout from the shelving of the Olympic Dam expansion and announcement that Holden’s Elizabeth factory would close ...
